trans-unit.source: Add sound
trans-unit.target: Add sound

trans-unit.source: In this step, we examine how the shooting game sample creates an object for sound playback using the XAudio2 APIs.
trans-unit.target: In this step, we examine how the shooting game sample creates an object for sound playback using the XAudio2 APIs.

trans-unit.source: Add sound
trans-unit.target: Add sound

trans-unit.source: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.
trans-unit.target: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

trans-unit.source: For Windows 8.x articles, see the [archive](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?linkid=619132) \]
trans-unit.target: For Windows 8.x articles, see the [archive](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?linkid=619132) \]

trans-unit.source: In this step, we examine how the shooting game sample creates an object for sound playback using the [XAudio2](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/ee415813) APIs.
trans-unit.target: In this step, we examine how the shooting game sample creates an object for sound playback using the [XAudio2](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/ee415813) APIs.

trans-unit.source: Objective
trans-unit.target: Objective

trans-unit.source: To add sound output using [XAudio2](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/ee415813).
trans-unit.target: To add sound output using [XAudio2](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/ee415813).

trans-unit.source: In the game sample, the audio objects and behaviors are defined in three files:
trans-unit.target: In the game sample, the audio objects and behaviors are defined in three files:

trans-unit.source: **Audio.h/.cpp**.
trans-unit.target: **Audio.h/.cpp**.

trans-unit.source: This code file defines the **Audio** object, which contains the XAudio2 resources for sound playback.
trans-unit.target: This code file defines the **Audio** object, which contains the XAudio2 resources for sound playback.

trans-unit.source: It also defines the method for suspending and resuming audio playback if the game is paused or deactivated.
trans-unit.target: It also defines the method for suspending and resuming audio playback if the game is paused or deactivated.

trans-unit.source: **MediaReader.h/.cpp**.
trans-unit.target: **MediaReader.h/.cpp**.

trans-unit.source: This code defines the methods for reading audio .wav files from local storage.
trans-unit.target: This code defines the methods for reading audio .wav files from local storage.

trans-unit.source: **SoundEffect.h/.cpp**.
trans-unit.target: **SoundEffect.h/.cpp**.

trans-unit.source: This code defines an object for in-game sound playback.
trans-unit.target: This code defines an object for in-game sound playback.

trans-unit.source: Defining the audio engine
trans-unit.target: Defining the audio engine

trans-unit.source: When the game sample starts, it creates an **Audio** object that allocates the audio resources for the game.
trans-unit.target: When the game sample starts, it creates an **Audio** object that allocates the audio resources for the game.

trans-unit.source: The code that declares this object looks like this:
trans-unit.target: The code that declares this object looks like this:

trans-unit.source: The **Audio::MusicEngine** and **Audio::SoundEffectEngine** methods return references to [**IXAudio2**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/ee415908) objects that define the mastering voice for each audio type.
trans-unit.target: The **Audio::MusicEngine** and **Audio::SoundEffectEngine** methods return references to [**IXAudio2**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/ee415908) objects that define the mastering voice for each audio type.

trans-unit.source: A mastering voice is the audio device used for playback.
trans-unit.target: A mastering voice is the audio device used for playback.

trans-unit.source: Sound data buffers cannot be submitted directly to mastering voices, but data submitted to other types of voices must be directed to a mastering voice to be heard.
trans-unit.target: Sound data buffers cannot be submitted directly to mastering voices, but data submitted to other types of voices must be directed to a mastering voice to be heard.

trans-unit.source: Initializing the audio resources
trans-unit.target: Initializing the audio resources

trans-unit.source: The sample initializes the [**IXAudio2**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/ee415908) objects for the music and sound effect engines with calls to [**XAudio2Create**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/ee419212).
trans-unit.target: The sample initializes the [**IXAudio2**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/ee415908) objects for the music and sound effect engines with calls to [**XAudio2Create**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/ee419212).

trans-unit.source: After the engines have been instantiated, it creates a mastering voice for each with calls to [**IXAudio2::CreateMasteringVoice**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/hh405048), as here:
trans-unit.target: After the engines have been instantiated, it creates a mastering voice for each with calls to [**IXAudio2::CreateMasteringVoice**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/hh405048), as here:

trans-unit.source: As a music or sound effect audio file is loaded, this method calls [**IXAudio2::CreateSourceVoice**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/ee418607) on the mastering voice, which creates an instance of a source voice for playback.
trans-unit.target: As a music or sound effect audio file is loaded, this method calls [**IXAudio2::CreateSourceVoice**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/ee418607) on the mastering voice, which creates an instance of a source voice for playback.

trans-unit.source: We look at the code for this as soon as we finish reviewing how the game sample loads audio files.
trans-unit.target: We look at the code for this as soon as we finish reviewing how the game sample loads audio files.

trans-unit.source: Reading an audio file
trans-unit.target: Reading an audio file

trans-unit.source: In the game sample, the code for reading audio format files is defined in **MediaReader.cpp**.
trans-unit.target: In the game sample, the code for reading audio format files is defined in **MediaReader.cpp**.

trans-unit.source: The specific method that reads in an encoded .wav audio file, **MediaReader::LoadMedia**, looks like this:
trans-unit.target: The specific method that reads in an encoded .wav audio file, **MediaReader::LoadMedia**, looks like this:

trans-unit.source: This method uses the [Media Foundation](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/ms694197) APIs to read in the .wav audio file as a Pulse Code Modulation (PCM) buffer.
trans-unit.target: This method uses the [Media Foundation](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/ms694197) APIs to read in the .wav audio file as a Pulse Code Modulation (PCM) buffer.

trans-unit.source: Creates a media source reader ([**IMFSourceReader**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/dd374655)) object by calling [**MFCreateSourceReaderFromURL**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/dd388110).
trans-unit.target: Creates a media source reader ([**IMFSourceReader**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/dd374655)) object by calling [**MFCreateSourceReaderFromURL**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/dd388110).

trans-unit.source: Creates a media type ([**IMFMediaType**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/ms704850)) for the decoding of the audio file by calling [**MFCreateMediaType**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/ms693861).
trans-unit.target: Creates a media type ([**IMFMediaType**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/ms704850)) for the decoding of the audio file by calling [**MFCreateMediaType**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/ms693861).

trans-unit.source: This method specifies that the decoded output is PCM audio, which is an audio type that XAudio2 can use.
trans-unit.target: This method specifies that the decoded output is PCM audio, which is an audio type that XAudio2 can use.

trans-unit.source: Sets the decoded output media type for the reader by calling [**IMFSourceReader::SetCurrentMediaType**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/bb970432).
trans-unit.target: Sets the decoded output media type for the reader by calling [**IMFSourceReader::SetCurrentMediaType**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/bb970432).

trans-unit.source: Creates a [**WAVEFORMATEX**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/hardware/ff538799) buffer and copies the results of a call to [**IMFMediaType::MFCreateWaveFormatExFromMFMediaType**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/ms702177) on the [**IMFMediaType**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/ms704850) object.
trans-unit.target: Creates a [**WAVEFORMATEX**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/hardware/ff538799) buffer and copies the results of a call to [**IMFMediaType::MFCreateWaveFormatExFromMFMediaType**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/ms702177) on the [**IMFMediaType**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/ms704850) object.

trans-unit.source: This formats the buffer that holds the audio file after it is loaded.
trans-unit.target: This formats the buffer that holds the audio file after it is loaded.

trans-unit.source: Gets the duration, in seconds, of the audio stream by calling [**IMFSourceReader::GetPresentationAttribute**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/dd374662) and then converts the duration to bytes.
trans-unit.target: Gets the duration, in seconds, of the audio stream by calling [**IMFSourceReader::GetPresentationAttribute**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/dd374662) and then converts the duration to bytes.

trans-unit.source: Reads the audio file in as a stream by calling [**IMFSourceReader::ReadSample**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/dd374665).
trans-unit.target: Reads the audio file in as a stream by calling [**IMFSourceReader::ReadSample**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/dd374665).

trans-unit.source: Copies the contents of the audio sample buffer into an array returned by the method.
trans-unit.target: Copies the contents of the audio sample buffer into an array returned by the method.

trans-unit.source: The most important thing in **SoundEffect::Initialize** is the creation of the source voice object, **m\_sourceVoice**, from the mastering voice.
trans-unit.target: The most important thing in **SoundEffect::Initialize** is the creation of the source voice object, **m\_sourceVoice**, from the mastering voice.

trans-unit.source: We use the source voice for the actual play back of the sound data buffer obtained from **MediaReader::LoadMedia**.
trans-unit.target: We use the source voice for the actual play back of the sound data buffer obtained from **MediaReader::LoadMedia**.

trans-unit.source: The sample game calls this method when it initializes the **SoundEffect** object, like this:
trans-unit.target: The sample game calls this method when it initializes the **SoundEffect** object, like this:

trans-unit.source: This method is passed the results of calls to **Audio::SoundEffectEngine** (or **Audio::MusicEngine**), **MediaReader::GetOutputWaveFormatEx**, and the buffer returned by a call to **MediaReader::LoadMedia**, as seen here.
trans-unit.target: This method is passed the results of calls to **Audio::SoundEffectEngine** (or **Audio::MusicEngine**), **MediaReader::GetOutputWaveFormatEx**, and the buffer returned by a call to **MediaReader::LoadMedia**, as seen here.

trans-unit.source: **SoundEffect::Initialize** is called from the **Simple3DGame:Initialize** method that initializes the main game object.
trans-unit.target: **SoundEffect::Initialize** is called from the **Simple3DGame:Initialize** method that initializes the main game object.

trans-unit.source: Now that the sample game has an audio file in memory, let's see how it plays it back during game play!
trans-unit.target: Now that the sample game has an audio file in memory, let's see how it plays it back during game play!

trans-unit.source: Playing back an audio file
trans-unit.target: Playing back an audio file

trans-unit.source: To play the sound, this method uses the source voice object **m\_sourceVoice** to start the playback of the sound data buffer **m\_soundData**.
trans-unit.target: To play the sound, this method uses the source voice object **m\_sourceVoice** to start the playback of the sound data buffer **m\_soundData**.

trans-unit.source: It creates an [**XAUDIO2\_BUFFER**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/ee419228), to which it provides a reference to the sound data buffer, and then submits it with a call to [**IXAudio2SourceVoice::SubmitSourceBuffer**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/ee418473).
trans-unit.target: It creates an [**XAUDIO2\_BUFFER**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/ee419228), to which it provides a reference to the sound data buffer, and then submits it with a call to [**IXAudio2SourceVoice::SubmitSourceBuffer**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/ee418473).

trans-unit.source: With the sound data queued up, **SoundEffect::PlaySound** starts play back by calling [**IXAudio2SourceVoice::Start**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/ee418471).
trans-unit.target: With the sound data queued up, **SoundEffect::PlaySound** starts play back by calling [**IXAudio2SourceVoice::Start**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/desktop/ee418471).

trans-unit.source: Now, whenever a collision between the ammo and a target occurs, a call to **SoundEffect::PlaySound** causes a noise to play.
trans-unit.target: Now, whenever a collision between the ammo and a target occurs, a call to **SoundEffect::PlaySound** causes a noise to play.

trans-unit.source: Next steps
trans-unit.target: Next steps

trans-unit.source: That was a whirlwind tour of Universal Windows Platform (UWP) DirectX game development!
trans-unit.target: That was a whirlwind tour of Universal Windows Platform (UWP) DirectX game development!

trans-unit.source: At this point, you have an idea of what you need to do to make your own game for Windows 8 a great experience.
trans-unit.target: At this point, you have an idea of what you need to do to make your own game for Windows 8 a great experience.

trans-unit.source: Remember, your game can be played on a wide variety of Windows 8 devices and platforms, so design your components: your graphics, your controls, your user interface, and your audio for as wide a set of configurations as you can!
trans-unit.target: Remember, your game can be played on a wide variety of Windows 8 devices and platforms, so design your components: your graphics, your controls, your user interface, and your audio for as wide a set of configurations as you can!

trans-unit.source: For more info about ways to modify the game sample provided in these documents, see [Extending the game sample](tutorial-resources.md).
trans-unit.target: For more info about ways to modify the game sample provided in these documents, see [Extending the game sample](tutorial-resources.md).
